review.title: A Soft Computing Model for Physicians' Decision Process
review.abstract: In this paper the author presents a kind of Soft Computing Technique, mainly an application of fuzzy set theory of Prof. Zadeh [16], on a problem of Medical Experts Systems. The choosen problem is on design of a physician's decision model which can take crisp as well as fuzzy data as input, unlike the traditional models. The author presents a mathematical model based on fuzzy set theory for physician aided evaluation of a complete representation of information emanating from the initial interview including patient past history, present symptoms, and signs observed upon physical examination and results of clinical and diagnostic tests.

metadata.title: A SOFT COMPUTING MODEL FOR PHYSICIANS’ DECISION PROCESS

sections.text: Index terms - Fuzzy Set, Hard Computing, Soft Computing, History, Symptom - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 1 INTRODUCTION Most of the mathematical models of the doctor's decision-making process offered so far, especially those relating to diagnosis and treatment [1-3,5,9-11,13,14], suffer from an inability to include all useful real data about the patient. Relevant information that is so neglected or poorly modelled relates to variables that are inherently blurred but describe the patient's state of health.

sections.heading: 1.1 WHAT IS SOFT COMPUTING?
sections.text: Soft computing differs from conventional (hard) computing in that (as opposed to hard computing etc.) it calculates the exploitation of tolerance for inaccuracy, uncertainty, partial truth and approximation. Basically, the model for soft computing is the human mind. The guiding principle of Soft Computing (SC) is: - Fuzzy Logic (FL), Rough Logic, Soft Set Logic, Neural Computing (NC), Genetic Computing, Evolutionary Computation (EC) Machine Learning (ML) and Probabilistic Reasoning (PR), the latter being faith networks, Fractal Oftness Theory, Probability Theory, Possibility Theory Qory and Learning Theory (ML) Machine Learning (PR). sections.heading: 2 THE GENERAL DIAGNOSTIC PROCESS: A
sections.text: SYSTEMS DESCRIPTION The diagnostic decision-making process is a sequence of decisions made by a physician in an attempt to identify and explain the symptoms, disorders and diseases of a particular patient. This process involves placing the patient in the care of a physician and collecting and evaluating relevant information at various intermittent stages. Such information, which is obtained through discussion, observation and testing, is important for the convergence of an effective pre- and final diagnosis. Figure I illustrates this process as well as the overall decision-making process in treatment. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Siddharta Sankar Biswas with the Gurgaon Institute of Tech-nology & Management, Gurgaon.
